rdf:Description.dct:title: Merging experiment data and simulation data for parameter identification of shaft seal
rdf:Description.dct:creator: Yuan Yin
Qiang He
Fengming Hu
Weifeng Huang

ja:head.ce:title: Merging experiment data and simulation data for parameter identification of shaft seal

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Tribology in Advanced Equipment, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Tribology in Advanced Equipment, Tsinghua University

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: State Key Laboratory of Tribology in Advanced Equipment, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A parameter identification method which merges experimentally monitored signals and physics-based simulation data is proposed, targeting the identification tasks in shaft seals which are challenging due to the high-dimensional parameter space. Features were extracted from the monitored acoustic emission signals following a proposed cross-timescale analysis routine, and the simulation data were augmented using Kriging surrogate model to obtain a dataset with stratified fidelity. Then, a transferable architecture of convolutional neural network modified for periodical data was proposed, with which part of the parameters trained by simulation data were reserved when training model using acoustic emission data acquired in experiments. Cross validation shows that transfer learning can effectively improve the performance, provided data augmentation and proper transfer mode. In conclusion, the study provides an effective parameter identification method which merges the simulation data which carry the physical knowledge and the experiment data which carry directly monitored results.

ce:list-item.ce:para: A method of performing parameter identification of shaft seal with acoustic emission monitoring is proposed. The method uses low-cost simulation data to pre-train, and uses reliable experiment data to fine-tune.

The manuscript describes the concrete measures for a good transferring, including introducing surrogate-model-based augmentation, performing auto-encoder to embed frequency spectrums, and designing the neural network architecture. These could be enlightening for audiences who are working on similar tasks.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: The data that has been used is confidential.

ce:section.ce:para: It is a common interest to identify the parameters of a mechanical system based on the monitored result of sensors. In some situations, because the physical model is not efficient and/or accurate enough, a practical approach is to establish a machine learning model which maps the signals to the parameters to be identified. Thereinto, deep learning is widely-used due to the strong and general function approximation capability [1–3]. However, deep learning demands huge amount of data, which are expensive to acquire.

Recent studies have been working on merging simulation results with experiment results to establish effective models. Denkena [4] trained support vector machine using both simulated features and monitored features to predict deformation of work piece. Finkeldey [5] used features derived by physical model to improve the performance of machine learning. Jiang [6] proposed a data fusion method by applying proper orthogonal decomposition technique to simulation results and the error between simulation and experiment results. Singh [7] established a data-augmented turbulence model for the inverse problem of airfoil flow. Gao [8] used a generative adversarial network to augment massive sample from a mixture of simulation and measurement data, therefore established an effective fault detection model. These studies in various fields proposed different solutions for a same purpose: to establish model by merging the simulated results and experiment data.

The presented work focuses on the shaft seal in rotary machines, whose parameter identification tasks are tough due to the high-dimensional parameter space. Such seals work with the seal interface relatively moving and thus typically suffer from various possible factors, including manufacturing or assembling error, deformation in operating, unexpected performances of supportive parts, etc. Diversified techniques have been introduced [9–17] for monitoring, and some studies further used machine learning technique for identifying the seal status [18–20]. Studies [21,22] have demonstrated that acoustic emission (AE) monitoring can detect rub-impact in mechanical face seals effectively.

In terms of simulation, many studies have provided tools and uncovered regulations [23–26], but there has been no study which instructs parameters identification with simulation yet. A major restriction is the count of undetermined parameters: kinds of potential causes of faults form a parameter space of high dimensionality. Therefore, it is too expensive to discuss the combined effect of parameters sufficiently or solve an inverse problem according to the monitored signals.

The study uses acoustic emission data as the major information source to establish modified convolutional neural network models, whose performance is improved by the support of simulation data based on transfer learning. For experiment data, features are extracted from the AE through a cross-timescale analysis routine. For simulation data, a method of establishing database with stratified fidelity is proposed to overcome the difficulty of high dimensionality. A transferable architecture of convolutional neural network (CNN) modified for periodical data is proposed. The model is first trained with simulation data, and then some of the layers were reserved in the new model which is then trained with experiment data. The proposed approach realizes a fusion of the expert knowledge carried by the simulation data and the directly measured data.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Experiment acoustic emission data and the feature extraction

ce:section.ce:para: Experiments were conducted to obtain the acoustic emission signals from the tribo-pair [22]. The rub-impact was mainly induced with a loading mechanism appended to the stator, and also depended on other factors including the rotor tilt, waviness and coning on both faces, and the unexpected performance of the flexible supports. Fig. 1 illustrates the tribo-pair influenced by the faults. The results of ten experiments list in Table 1 will be used, with varying load, two different rotor tilt values (group A with 46 μrad and group B with 144 μrad), and fixed pressure (4 atmG) and speed (1200 rpm). An acoustic emission sensor is appended on the stator. It acquires signal at a sample rate of 2 MSps.

By looking into the acoustic emission signals acquired (as shown in Fig. 2), it was found that the signals exhibit characteristics including concentration near specific frequencies with discrepant modes, informative periodical fluctuations, and quasi-periodicity during specific phase in starting and stopping.

The task is defined as establishing a regression model to identify the eccentric load applied by the loading mechanism. The validation is to be performed under a strict cross-validation policy, where the data is split into two groups (A and B) by the rotor tilt. That is, the model is trained using data with uniform rotor tilt, but is to be validated on data with different rotor tilt value. Such case is typical in practice, where the huge amount of data may come from a few of consistent operations.

Based on the studies into the signal characteristics, the signals in 3s∼7s after starting and before stopping are adopted, where the speed underwent increasing or decreasing and thus generated diverse data, as marked in Fig. 2. That is, two segments are taken from each of the 10 experiments. A cross-timescale representation routine is proposed to extract the features. The spectrum of each short-time wave (or “frame”) is embedded into a low-dimensionality space, and the fluctuations are resampled on synchronous time steps.
Each frame with 1024 samples generates an amplitude spectrum u∗={uj∗}1×512. A preprocessing is applied by smoothing u∗2 as below. (1)u=u∗2T(2)T=tij,tij=1σ2πexp−(i−j)22σ2where σ=2.5.

The preprocessed spectrum is embedded using an auto-encoder with a multilayer perceptron architecture (as shown in Fig. 3 to reconstruct the preprocessed spectrum u). The auto-encoder embeds the spectrum into a length-Mf vector η. Here, Mf=16. (3)η=enc(u)(4)uˆ=dec(η)

The AE signals went through non-stationary fluctuations along with the shaft rotation. Because the data contain quasi-periodic phases where the period varies, a synchronous resample is performed to normalize the count of time steps in each period to L=50. For segment is(is=1,2,…,20), given the embedded spectrums ηj at tηj(j=Mis−1+1,Mis−1+2,…,Mis) and the synchronous steps tξi(i=Nis−1+1,Nis−1+2,…,Nis), the interpolated vectors ξi are obtained as (5)ξi=ηj+tξi−tηjtηj+1−tηj(ηj+1−ηj),iftηj≤tξi<tηj+1

Each sequential L=50 resampled vectors (6)x(i)=ξiT,ξi+1T,…,ξi+L−1TT(i=Nis−1+1,Nis−1+2,…,Nis−L+1)are considered as an input to the model, namely the input shape is (50,16). The corresponding y(i) is the eccentric load of the experiment (the second column in Table 1).
The architecture of the model which maps x(i) to y(i) will be introduced later in Section 4.
A dynamic model considering transient lubrication and contact is adopted to simulate the seal affected by various kinds of faults. The components of the model are briefly described below [23].

The stator is regarded as moving in three degrees-of-freedom (zs, γsx, γsy, denoting axial displacement and rotation around X-axis and Y-axis for the stator, respectively), controlled by the dynamic equations. The motion of rotor (similarly denoted as zr, γrx, γry) is assumed as fixed. (7)Us=Zsγsxγsy,Ur=zrγrxγry=0γrx0cosωt+γry0sinωt−γrx0sinωt+γry0cosωt(8)h=h0+hgrooves+hdeform+1y−xUs−Ur=h0∗+1y−xUs−Ur

Here, h is the gas film thickness defined on the annulus area Ω=(x,y)|ri≤x2+y2≤ro, within which hgrooves denotes the contribution of the grooves. Besides the macroscopic kinematics, the seal rings submit to planeness errors, regarded as consisting of coning and waviness, denoted by hdeform. The former one is denoted by tapper δ. The latter one is extremely complexed. According to Lebeck [27], a harmonic representation can be applied for waviness, where the low order compositions are commonly focused. With limitation in the 2nd and 3rd harmonics, 8 parameters are necessary to describe the waviness on stator and rotor, considering the phases. (9)hdeform=∑n=23hwsn2cos(nθ)+∑n=23hwsn2sin(nθ)+∑n=23hwrn2cos(n(θ+ωt))+∑n=23hwrn2sin(n(θ+ωt))+δ(r−ri)(ro−ri)

The gas is considered to be ideal and inertia-free, with constant temperature and viscosity, and the flow is considered laminar and non-slipping at the boundary. The absolute gas pressure in the film, p, is governed by the transient average flow Reynolds equation [28] with Dirichlet boundary conditions, given by (10)∇⋅φph312μ∇p=ω∂(ph)2∂θ+∂(ph)∂t,pr=ri=pipr=ro=po(11)φ=1−0.9exp−0.56hσwhere t is the time, r and θ are the radius and angle in polar coordinates, respectively, μ is the gas dynamic viscosity, and σa is the standard deviation of the surface height.

A wide range of faults or low-speed operation may result in contact. According to Fan [29], the light face contact can be considered as elastic. Considering the summit heights to obey a Gaussian distribution, the contact is simulated as [30](12)pc=pc(h)=43YηsRs12∫h∞(w−h)32σsϕw−w̄sσsdwwhere ϕ(⋅) denotes the probability density function of the standard normal distribution. The equivalent roughness parameters of the contact pair include Y, ηs, Rs, ws̄ and σs, referring to elastic modulus, asperity density, average asperity radius, mean of asperity height and standard deviation of asperity height, respectively.

Face contact will generate acoustic emissions for monitoring. However, there is no existing research about the explanation on the frequency distribution of acoustic emissions. The most applicable study is the model of short-time root-mean-square (RMS) as [29,31](13)V=KV0=K∬Ω25ωrYηs∫h∞(w−h)2σsϕw−w̄sσsdwwhere K is the coefficient describing the transmission from the acoustic emission source to the signal sent out by the sensor, assumed to be constant, and V is the RMS value of the signal.
The motion of the flexibly mounted stator is governed by: (14)MÜs+CsU̇s+KsUs=Ff+Fc+Fb+F(15)M=diag(m,J,J)Cs=diagcsz,csγ,csγKs=diagksz,ksγ,ksγ

The damping and stiffness, assumed linear according to Miller [23], are considered as being potentially abnormal, and are modeled as being scaled by Qs, that is: (16)ksz,ksγ,csz,csγ=Qsksz0,ksγ0,csz0,csγ0
The generalized forces in Eq. (14) are calculated as (17)Ff=FfMxfMyf=∬ΩpdΩ∬ΩpydΩ−∬ΩpxdΩT(18)Fc=FcMxcMyc=∬ΩpcdΩ∬ΩpcydΩ−∬ΩpcxdΩT(19)Fb=Fb00T(20)F=FMxMyT

Here, Fb has only one component, Fb, which comes from the pressure at the back of the stator and the preload. Fb is equal to Ff when Us−Ur=0 (note that Fc=0 at the designed state as in a non-contacting seal), which is how h0 is determined. F contains the faults which are modeled by the forces or moments on the stator.

Concerning the common potential faults in the seals, the parameters listed in Table 2 are considered as varying when establishing simulation dataset. The axial compactness change can be represented as an axial force F exerted on the stator. The asymmetry of the stator support is abstracted into the moments Mx and My. The stiffness and damping of the stator support may differ from their design performance because of assembly faults or aging, and are thus modeled using a scaling coefficient Qs. The rotor tilt components γrx0 and γry0 commonly occur because of assembly errors. Coning δ and waviness (in a limited harmonic representation with hsc2,…,hrs2) describes the deformation of the faces. The speed ω is considered variable as the experiment data during speeding up and down are used.

This coupled system was solved through the finite element method with a commercial software. A static simulation (which assumes Us−Ur=0) is first performed to yield a static pressure field, and then the dynamic simulation is performed. 3 periods are simulated and the last 2 periods are exported.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Establishing simulation dataset with stratified fidelity
ce:section.ce:para: Though easier to be obtained than experiment data, the computational cost of simulation data is still considerable, especially in such a high-dimensional parameter space (see Table 2). Therefore, a three-step approach was proposed to generate the simulation dataset. Firstly, with a Latin hypercube design (LHD), a limited count of sampling sites properly filling the parameter space are generated, on which the physical model is evaluated to obtain the primary data. Secondly, on a greater count of sampling sites (also generated using LHD), low-fidelity data were augmented through interpolation using a Kriging surrogate model. Finally, segments with different phases are created by a moving one-period window.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Latin hypercube design and the primary data
ce:section.ce:para: Commonly used test design methods for computer experiments include full factorial design, fractional factorial design, central composite design, Box–Behnken design, Latin hypercube design (LHD), maximum entropy design, minimum integrated mean square error design, maximin/minimax design, and ϕp-design [32,33]. The LHD approach is convenient and effective in high-dimensional cases and is thus adopted.
For M0 sites with P variables (P=16 here), the LHD scheme can be denoted as [34] below.
A matrix D is generated, each column of which is a random permutation of 0 to M0−1. (21)D=dijM0×P

Considering the parameters as uniformly distributed, the parameters are then randomly generated according to the level indices dij as: (22)ζj(i)∗=Dj−1dij+δijM0,i=1,2,…,M0,j=1,2,…,Pwhere ζj(i)∗ denotes F,Mx,My,…,ω for j=1,2,3,…,16 at site i, and Dj is the respective cumulative distribution function (CDF), as listed in Table 2 and shown in Fig. 4. δij is uniformly distributed from 0 to 1.

M0=1000 sites are determined using LHD, on which the physical model is evaluated. The resulted V0 is sampled at (2L−1) time steps to obtain z˜(i)∗=z1(i)∗z2(i)∗⋯z2L−1(i)∗, where the time increment is Δt=T/L, L=50 is chosen in consider of covering the first- and second-order oscillations of the 12 spiral grooves on the rotor face.

The evaluation may fail accidentally because of extreme parameter. There were 8 evaluations failed in this way, and thus the primary data contain M0∗=992 samples eventually. Some of the results are plotted in Fig. 5, which undergo two periods. The curves are distinctive by features including multiple peaks, the heights and duration of peaks and valleys, minor peaks, etc. The features are consistent with experiments (see Fig. 2).
Due to the limited count, the physical evaluation sites distribute sparsely in the high-dimensional parameter space. In order to mitigate this problem, low-fidelity data are generated as supplement.

Targeting at M1=10000 sites after augmentation, M1∗=M1−M0∗=9008 sample sites are determined with LHD. As a model regarded effective for small dataset and strongly nonlinear function, Kriging model is adopted to interpolate on these sites [32,35].

Standardization is first applied to each of the P undetermined parameters (F,Mx,My,…,ω) to obtain vectors formatted as ζ˜(i)=ζ1(i)ζ2(i)⋯ζP(i), and is applied to V0 of all time steps to obtain z˜(i)=z1(i)z2(i)⋯z2L−1(i).
The Kriging model assumes (23)zj=fpoly(ζ)+Gj(ζ)(j=1,2,…,2L−1)where fpoly is a deterministic polynomial trend model (using 2nd-order polynomial here) and Gj is a Gaussian process.

Given the standardized dataset {(ζ˜(i),z˜(i))}i=1,…,M0∗ (by performing standardization on the results of Section 3.2.1, the Kriging model can be established to interpolate at a general site ζ˜ to yield an estimated z˜ˆ. The detailed algorithm generally follows Sacks [35], modified with a Nugget effect [36] for robustness.
After the augmentation, M1=10000 pairs of (ζ˜(i),z˜(i)) are ready. In Section 4.2, the impact of the augmented data will be discussed.

In order to cover the cases of different phases, a one-period-length moving window is applied to each z˜(i)=z1(i)z2(i)⋯z2L−1(i), obtaining z1(i)z2(i)⋯zL(i), z2(i)z3(i)⋯zL+1(i), …, till zL(i)zL+1(i)⋯z2L−1(i).A segmented output observation is denoted by z.

Eventually, 500000 observations are collected for the simulation dataset, with only 1000 evaluations of the physical model. Each observation is a pair of parameters ζ˜ and dynamic contact AE intensity z, both standardized.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Parameter identification method with transfer learning
ce:section.ce:para: Following the steps proposed in Section 2, the frequency distribution, the periodical fluctuation and semi-periodicity during speed changing had been exploited, and the task was defined as to identify the eccentric loaded exerted in the experiments using the features exploited. The simulation data had been augmented following the approaches proposed in Section 3. The combination of the two types of data was performed with transfer learning, as described below.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Transferable convolutional neural network architecture modified for periodical data
ce:section.ce:para: Convolutional neural network (CNN) [37–39] is chosen for the task, where the time varying of data carries the information of the seal state.

Models using simulation data are first established. The layers to be transferred is expected to extract the dynamic features most related to the eccentric load exerted in experiments, which is targeted in the task. Therefore, the axial force and moment magnitude is adopted as model output. Standardization is applied to each of the two parameters, obtaining ζ=ζ1ζ2, in which ζ1 is the standardized F and ζ2 is the standardized Mx2+My2.
Two hyperparameters are left undetermined to be discussed later: u denotes the embedding dimensionality, and s denotes the size of CNN filters.

Considering the periodicity, the CNN architecture is modified by extending for the convolutional filters. Let hI=h1Ih2I⋯hLIT=zdenotes the input to the first modified convolutional module. The module is denoted as (24)fijI=ReLU∑m=1scmjIhi′I+bjI,j=1,2,…,u,i′=i+m−1,i=1,2,…,L−s+1i+m−1−L,i=L−s+2,…,L(25)hijII=maxm=1,2f(i+m−1)jI,i=1,2,…,L′,j=1,2,…,u,L′=L/2

The output of pooling (Eq. 4.1), hII, is sequentially passed through another modified convolutional module to extract deep features, which can be denoted as (26)fijII=ReLU∑n=1u∑m=1scmnjIIhi′nII+bjII,j=1,2,…,u,i′=i+m−1,i=1,2,…,L′−s+1i+m−1−L′,i=L′−s+2,…,L′(27)hijIII=maxm=1,2,…,5f(i+m−1)jII,i=1,2,…,L″,j=1,2,…,u,L″=L′/5
Lastly, hIII is flattened for a fully connected layer towards output ζˆ. (28)ζˆi=∑m=1L″∑n=1u(kmniouthmnIII)+biout,i=1,2
The next step is to establish the model trained with experiment data, with transferred modules from simulation data.

The input is the second order tensor xij, each row of which is an embedded frequency spectrum and is further projected to a scaler with a learned layer to adapt for the model using simulation data, namely (29)hiI=∑j=1Mfkjinxij+bin
The output module is substituted for similar reason. (30)yˆ=∑i=1ukioutIIReLU∑m=1L″∑n=1ukmniouthmnIII+bioutI+boutII
Mean square error (MSE) is adopted as the loss function for both.
The whole architecture is shown in Fig. 6.
With varying hyperparameters s (in 3,4,5) and u (in 16,32,64,128,256), the performances of 4 different transfer modes are compared:
(1) Not transferred. No information from simulation data is used.
(2) Module 1 transferred. The weights of module 1 trained by simulation data is reserved and fixed during training with experiment data.
(3) Module 2 transferred. The weights of module 2 trained by simulation data is reserved and fixed during training with experiment data.
(4) Modules 1 and 2 transferred. The weights of modules 1 and 2 trained by simulation data are both reserved and fixed during training with experiment data.
For each pair of (s,u), the same initial weights is shared by all models on the layers where transfer is not applied.
Besides the 4 transfer modes, the impact of surrogate-model-based data augmentation is also discussed.
Cross-validation is conducted as described in Section 2). The RSE (root square error) is shown in Table 3.

Firstly, the transfer modes and simulation data augmentation are discussed with hyper-parameters fixed at s=4 and u=64. Fig. 7 shows the distribution of identified results of the observations in cross validation, with statistics including the median (marked with the points) and the quartiles (marked with the bars). The results shown in the first row in Fig. 7 used simulation data which were not augmented whenever performing transfer, and the results shown in the second row used those which were augmented. All models are accurate in situations with light load, but the error increases with the increasing load, where the models show differences in performance. The identified load for A4 and A5 are systematically underestimated, and minor errors occurs for A3, B3, B4 and B5. The surrogate-model-based augmentation of the simulation data are proved effective by a vertical comparison in Fig. 7. With the augmentation applied, the transfer learning can improve the performance of the CNN model, within which transferring Module 1 results in the best improvement (RSE from 0.244 to 0.157, decreasing by 35.7%). Without the augmentation, only transferring Modules 1 and 2 can improve the performance slightly (6.1%), and is weaker than the same transfer mode using augmentation (9.4%).

According to the results under s=4 and u=64, it can be found that the most effective configuration is to use augmentation and transfer Module 1. The RSEs listed in Table 3 support this conclusion: For 12 of the 15 pairs of s and u, to use augmentation and transfer Module 1 results in the best performance, and the configuration also performs well for the other 3 pairs of s and u.

Fig. 8 further shows the impact of augmentation and hyperparameters when transferring Module 1. When augmentation is not applied, the transfer may slightly improve or impair the performance. With augmentation, all cases benefit from transfer significantly (except the case with s=4, u=16 which only improves less than 1% by transfer). The difference between transfer learning cases with and without augmentation can be attributed to the sparsity of the directly simulated data (49250 observations in a 16-dimensional space), which was remitted by introducing the augmentation process. This provides an auxiliary tool for simulation-data-based machine learning studies.

Fig. 9 discusses the impact of transfer mode and hyperparameters when using augmentation. As mentioned above, the combination of augmentation and transferring Module 1 is effective and stable. The performance of the other 2 transfer modes is unstable. The probable reason is that the count of parameters in Module 2 is so huge that the model is weak in adaptability when the parameters are fixed. Therefore, transferring Module 1 is the proper transfer mode in the proposed architecture.

Fig. 10 illustrates the detailed comparison of the truth and the cross validation output along the operation phases using s=4,u=64, augmentation and transferring Module 1. It also shows that the model performs better in situations where light loads are applied.

In conclusion, the proposed surrogate-model-based augmentation strengthens the effectiveness of transfer learning from simulation data. A proper proportion of transferred parameters which balances the transferred knowledge and the reserved trainability is necessary. A transfer learning using the proposed CNN architecture modified for periodical data following the rules above can improve the model performance.

A method merging experiment data and simulation data for parameter identification task of shaft seals is proposed and demonstrated, which is based on the acoustic emission monitoring and a transfer learning approach with convolutional neural networks.

(1) A convolutional neural network architecture which is modified for periodical data and designed for performing transfer learning is proposed. Cross validation is conducted and demonstrated that a transfer learning with the proposed architecture can establish an effective model which identifies the fault parameter using acoustic emission input.

(2) A cross-timescale analysis routine is proposed in order to exploit informative features from acoustic emissions signals generated by rub-impact. It represents the frequency distribution and dynamic fluctuation of the signals separately to organize the features governed by different types of physical factors properly.

(3) Due to limited calculation resources and the high dimensionality of the parameter space, the directly simulated data is too sparse for an effective transfer. A surrogate-model-based augmentation method is proposed to remit the problem and is demonstrated. This is generally enlightening for simulation-data-based machine learning studies.

Yuan Yin: Writing – original draft, Visualization, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis. Qiang He: Visualization, Software, Conceptualization. Fengming Hu: Writing – review & editing, Investigation, Data curation. Weifeng Huang: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Resources, Project administration, Investigation, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization.
